specialty_reason: I don't see myself as being that much hands on. Also the culture and work life balance is not something I see myself enjoying in the future. The residents work an insane amount of hours and have to function on next to no sleep which I doesn't appeal to me. The culture of surgery can also be intimidating and it can be a very unwelcoming environment.
specialty_change: Culture change
orthopaedics: Gender bias (mostly male), poor culture, life in residency
general_surgery: Life in residency

specialty_reason: Mysoginy and the residency

discouragement_reason: Several surgical residents stating "life sucks" "the residency is too much work" "you don't make enough money for the work"
ob_gyn: Female dominated. Men are sometimes refused by patients limiting experience and making me concerned about a possible future career.
plastic_surgery: Aesthetic surgery is part of plastic surgery that can be viewed as a self esteem building factor in a patient's life, which is an important part of her healthcare. Attendings who participate in interviews have stated that mentioning aesthetic surgery is a detriment to interviewees despite it being a part of the specialty.

specialty_reason: Lifestyle mainly, and personalities that I worked with in surgery are not what I look for in a colleague
specialty_change: Better work-life balance, especially in residency but also as an attending  Culture is toxic with a lot of people who are egotistical and "type A" - worked with a lot of hot heads who only cared about themselves and not the others in the OR room or the patient

specialty_reason: I was very interested in a surgical specialty and was planning on pursuing, but in third year rotations I experienced a different specialty that better fit with my overall goals and values as a future physician
specialty_change: I only had very positive experiences in surgery. There was nothing about the culture or expectations that turned me away from the specialty.

specialty_reason: Learning Culture, time demand,
specialty_change: The culture around having a life outside of surgery is almost frowned upon and looked at as being less committed to the speciality. The mentality that surgeons are the "top dogs"
orthopaedics: No jobs
general_surgery: "Top dog" mentality
ob_gyn: The culture

specialty_reason: Long and unpredictable hours, poor work-life balance, culture is not very friendly and does not seem to prioritize personal wellbeing
specialty_change: The above listed factors would have to be improved
discouragement_reason: Not a specific situation, rather than a combination of trainees and staff in surgical and non-surgical specialties advising against it, mainly due to mentions of poor work life balance, high stress

specialty_reason: The lifestyle during residency.
specialty_change: The hours during residency don't seem healthy or safe to me, particularly residents working "home call" for 72 hours when they're in the hospital operating for most of those hours. There's also a culture of devoting your life to the operating room, even when you're a staff surgeon, that I don't agree with.
discouragement_reason: I've been open with many peers and non-surgical residents about my desire to pursue family medicine, and have been told that's a good idea and that pursuing surgery isn't. I've had many surgical residents be very encouraging about my pursuing surgery should I want it, but they're honest about their hours and the challenges they face.
orthopaedics: The "bro" culture. Gender bias and sexism.
general_surgery: The hours. The stress load and acuity of many patients.
ob_gyn: Mean culture.
urology: The competitiveness and hours.
neurosurgery: The competitiveness, hours, and lack of job opportunity when done residency.
are_there_any_other_specif: Having to do a fellowship after training to be competitive. The lack of freedom in choosing where you want to live and practice even when you're done training.

specialty_reason: Because of the staff/residents. not the type of people I would want to work with- minimal collegiality
specialty_change: Absolutely. Surgery itself is wonderful. it's life saving. it's interesting. Unfortunately, the second I stepped into clerkship in surgery, I was made to feel unwelcome. unlike other specialities where they try to convince the clerk to join, surgeons do the opposite.  The communication between surgeons to patients is also appalling, to be frank. I have never witnessed such crude breaking of bad news than I did in my surgery block.
discouragement_reason: So many events. I will say that the orthopaedic surgeons I worked with were incredible and they said Inwould be great. I was mostly discouraged from pursuing general surgery - mostly by the residents who said if I have any hobbies outside or medicine, or if i want a family, or if i want to be happy, i shouldn't do it.
orthopaedics: I got along with them very well. they were awesome to me. that being said, and i will be frank, i am a sporty person. They were not as kind (residents) to my classmates who were not sporty, or who did not belong to the "bro" club.
general_surgery: everything was a barrier.
ob_gyn: na
urology: na
cardiac_surgery: terribly rude to absolutely all students
are_there_any_other_specif: I think I covered it. thank you for this survey. I apologize for how blunt my responses were, but i hope it helps with future decision making

specialty_reason: difficult lifestyle in residency, poor job market, poor mobility, workplace culture does not prioritize work/life balance
specialty_change: better work-life balance
discouragement_reason: General comments from people outside the speciality
ob_gyn: too many call shifts

specialty_reason: Culture of surgery, long hours, long residency, I can see a life other than surgery
specialty_change: More work life balance. Culture such that eating lunch at lunch time is not considered slacking etc.
orthopaedics: None but other surgeons think you dont understand medical Problems
general_surgery: Long hours, notorious for shame learning
ob_gyn: Being male
urology: Being female
are_there_any_other_specif: No

specialty_reason: Not skilled with hands. Prefer lifestyle specialties.
specialty_change: No
ob_gyn: Toxic attitudes among trainees, difficult to foster close relationships.

specialty_change: 5am starts and poor job prospects after with no work life balance was challenging to consider it as a specialty.
are_there_any_other_specif: Poor job prospects in Canada. The need to do US fellowships.

orthopaedics: It's a 'bro's club' and you need to be quite strong. When I've been in ORs with ortho it's been a lot of sports talk that i cannot participate in
general_surgery: None
ob_gyn: None
vascular_surgery: No specific barriers but no exposure
urology: Similar to ortho, feels like a men's club
neurosurgery: Was specifically told by female residents not to expect to have any family life and was told there were no jobs
cardiac_surgery: Did not hear the best reputation about the trainees here, was told there were some anti-Semitic comments made to a fellow medical student

specialty_reason: I was not interested in the hours, always being tied to the hospital.
discouragement_reason: Told not to do surgery if wanted a family - will have little time for them.
orthopaedics: No jobs
general_surgery: Male dominated
ob_gyn: No respect from other surgical disciplines
urology: N/a
are_there_any_other_specif: N/a

specialty_reason: During my surgical rotations I experienced extremely disrespectful behaviour of staff towards residents and medical students. Name calling, insinuating stupidity. Extreme arrogance. I would never want to be associated with this profession.
specialty_change: The culture
general_surgery: Rude and disrespectful staff

vascular_surgery: Only 10 spots across Canada per year, difficulty establishing rapport with relevant personnel at home campus because I am at a satellite campus, difficulty creating opportunities outside of scheduled learning during clerkship to gain specific skills in this field to impress on fourth year electives

specialty_reason: Lifestyle; culture; personalities.
specialty_change: I would pursue if it weren't for the above reasons
orthopaedics: Gender issues; lifestyle (hours); bullying
general_surgery: Bullying; lifestyle; personality
ob_gyn: Not experienced
urology: Lifestyle (hours)
are_there_any_other_specif: Mostly lifestyle, attending personalities, sometimes toxic culture, sometimes bullying

specialty_change: lifestyle factors

specialty_reason: culture
specialty_change: Hierarchical culture, call requirements, limiting job opportunities (depending on the specialty) and overall poor work-life balance
orthopaedics: Poor job market and poor work-life balance, especially as a resident
general_surgery: toxic culture
ob_gyn: bias as a male and difficult residency
urology: Niche specialty
ent: Niche specialty, highly competitive for CARMS
neurosurgery: Poor work life balance and call requirements
cardiac_surgery: Poor work life balance and job market

specialty_reason: Don't enjoy operating enough to deal with all the culture issues
specialty_change: Long hours, mean environment for learners, over worked compared to other specialities, etc

specialty_reason: Because the residency and staff life is too demanding and is not conducive to having a life outside of medicine, from what I've seen and heard.
specialty_change: Yes, if the culture was more supportive of having a life outside of medicine.
discouragement_reason: Docs, both surgeons and non surgeons, telling me that you have to be a work a holic to go into surgery

specialty_reason: Long hours, weekend long call as senior resident, expected to not take post call days, majority of residents do not seem happy. Most likely will have to do a fellowship as well
specialty_change: Better call system, protected post call days.
orthopaedics: Ortho trauma block was extremely difficult. Very long hours, with very early rounding times.
general_surgery: Senior residents looked unhappy. Senior residents I worked with did not treat me with respect and talked down to me.
vascular_surgery: Did not have a rotation in this.
urology: Did not have a rotation in this.
ent: Did not have a rotation in this.
plastic_surgery: Did not have a rotation in this.
neurosurgery: Did not have a rotation in this.
cardiac_surgery: Did not have a rotation in this.

specialty_reason: Lifestyle, particularly in residency
specialty_change: More humane residency (in terms of hours especially)

specialty_reason: Reasons for enjoying surgery not the reasons I went into medicine. Would not be able to maintain the work-life balance I'm looking for at this stage of my life.
specialty_change: Less 'all consuming' residency training. More extensive patient interactions.

specialty_reason: Length & intensity of training, culture, difficulty to manage family & relationships, technical skill, endurance needed, ability to survive on little sleep
specialty_change: Culture shift, shorter shifts/less call
discouragement_reason: On "a surgical block", I was told that it would be hard to do "said surgical block" (which I am still semi interested in) unless I had a supportive partner with a "less intense/demanding" job; and told it would be difficult to handle as my current partner is also in professional school for an intense/demanding career
orthopaedics: male dominated, "ortho bro" stereotype
ob_gyn: difficult call schedule/long hours, apparently needed to figure out this was a specialty I wanted earlier on in med school than clerkship to have a good chance at matching

specialty_reason: Training is too long. Culture of surgical subspecialties can be unsupportive. I'm more interested in a more general field.
Interested in primary care.
specialty_change: Unlikely.
orthopaedics: Requires fellowship(s) to find a job in Canada. Long hours in residency. Subspecialization means doing the same surgeries repeatedly.
general_surgery: High call burden throughout residency and as staff. Culture not supportive.
ob_gyn: Patients prefer feminine-presenting providers.
vascular_surgery: High-stress surgeries. Long cases. Personally uninterested.
urology: Limited variety of pathology. Personally uninterested.
cardiac_surgery: Minimal variety in surgeries. Long cases. Personally uninterested.

specialty_reason: job opportunities, length of training, decision made with partner
specialty_change: Job opportunity and flexibility

discouragement_reason: Surgeons at different club events have mentioned that it is a very difficult career choice and that they recommend that if I am passionate about something other than surgery then to pursue that.
orthopaedics: Very male dominated field with a "fratty" atmosphere
ob_gyn: Very intense call schedule and hours. Very high highs but very low lows.

specialty_reason: Because I am interested in a hands-on specialty, and like the skill-based nature of general surgery.
discouragement_reason: I was discouraged by an IM doctor to pursue general surgery due to the challenges in having a family during surgical training. I have also been discouraged by surgeons who said to pursue specialities like gastroenterology instead for the same reason.
orthopaedics: Heavily male-dominated feild deters females from pursuing.May be challenging for women to find mentors in this field.
general_surgery: Difficult residency, which also occurs during years where most woman would start to think about having children.
ob_gyn: Overall, most OB/GYN attendings and residents I have met are not particularly nice people.
vascular_surgery: Male-dominated field. Patient population is extremely old and complex. outcomes are poor.
urology: Male-dominated field. May get bias from patients as a urologist who is a woman.
ent: I do not know much about this field.
plastic_surgery: i feel that representation between men and women is quite good in this field. Lifestyle also seems better than other surgical specialties.
neurosurgery: Male dominated. Long residency and very limited jobs.
cardiac_surgery: I do not know much about this field.
are_there_any_other_specif: No

specialty_reason: The culture is terrible in my experience. The hours are unnecessarily long. Not worth it.
specialty_change: Hours need to be more reasonable (and YES it can be done). We need post call days. No one should be operating post call. The culture needs to change. Stop treating each other like angry entitled children.
general_surgery: Culture is by far the worst within all surgical specialties
ob_gyn: Second worse culture.
cardiac_surgery: The fact that you are repeatedly told there are no jobs in Canada for you after you graduate and you have to love to the US was a major reason I walked away from this. This was a huge interest of mine and I still think about it.
are_there_any_other_specif: I would've loved to pursue surgery. I'm not afraid of working hard, or working hard and for long hours, but the lack of post call days and the terrible culture that is so easily palpable and so many of the surgical subspecialties that I have been exposed to just make it a really uninticing option

discouragement_reason: Happens on a daily basis. Usually comments related to culture, work/life balance, tough residency etc.
orthopaedics: Gender gap
general_surgery: Racialized and visible minority status
ob_gyn: Working hours
urology: N/A
cardiac_surgery: Gender gap big time. I worked with one female fellow in my entire time on Cardiac surgery, and she was actually rotating off-service
are_there_any_other_specif: Respectfully, these questions miss a huge visible gap in surgical trainees: race and visible minority status. It influences my interactions every day and alienates me more than my gender does.

specialty_reason: Love of the technique and skill it takes to perform surgeries. Desire to help people through interventions.
discouragement_reason: People saying I shouldn't pursue it due to poor work life balance and increased stress.
orthopaedics: Tough work life balance within residency.
general_surgery: Overbearing supervisors
ob_gyn: Constant on call
are_there_any_other_specif: None

specialty_reason: Maybe- it is interesting stuff but I have heard the residency is very demanding and the job market can not be so good
specialty_change: 1. Less demanding residency   2. Better job opportunities within Canada upon graduation
discouragement_reason: I have been told the residency is very challenging and there are easier specialties I should pursue
orthopaedics: No jobs, I do not like the content of this material
general_surgery: I don't like the content of this material
ob_gyn: Being on call for deliveries when you are a staff, chaos in the OR during C sections
vascular_surgery: Don't have enough exposure to comment on
urology: Don't have enough exposure to comment on
ent: Hard residency and long reconstructive cases, large acquisition of anatomy knowledge
plastic_surgery: Don't have enough exposure to comment on
neurosurgery: Long training, need for a PhD to pursue jobs in Canada, very competitive
cardiac_surgery: Long training, very competitive, not material I am interested in

discouragement_reason: Resident who dropped out from general surgery and now is in FM was very adamant that the surgical lifestyle was not suitable for anybody.
orthopaedics: Potential need for physical strength/understanding own body mechanics to leverage strength
general_surgery: Okay with dealing with poop
ob_gyn: Able to manage the high risk deliveries
are_there_any_other_specif: Fluctuating/limited job prospects after fellowship

specialty_reason: Genuine interest despite many barriers
discouragement_reason: I have been advised about difficulty in family planning, work life balance, the competitiveness of my application, I have been told by male residents that I lack confidence.
ent: Heavily male dominated, with minimal female mentors.
are_there_any_other_specif: Gruelling and isolating carms process that feels, in many ways, dehumanizing.

specialty_reason: Prefer primary care
specialty_change: I find it physically difficult, and I prefer to spend time interacting with patients

specialty_reason: Poor job availability in general (I don't want my career to dictate where I live), and I already have fertility problems and I would expect the long hours and stress of a surgical residency would make children impossible (if they aren't already).
specialty_change: From my perspective as a clerk I think the programs are unnecessarily long. Residents seem to graduate unsure of b performing bread and butter operations - I think this is because they spend too much time in the first two years off-service/doing scut work that doesn't appear helpful to learning. Part of the reason programs might do this is because the majority of residents go on to do a fellowship, so it seems like most of their independence is earned there. Surgical residency sounds like a bit of a pyramid scheme.    In my twenties I think I might have been interested, but now I just don't have the time. And while most of my interactions have been pleasant, some of the most unpleasant people I've met have been in surgery (I'm talking attendings, residents, and fellows).
discouragement_reason: I was on ortho, and maybe had a bit of Stockholm syndrome, but I expressed to a male Fellow "I am enjoying this, maybe I should do ortho" and he just looked and me and said "you don't want to do that."  This guy didn't even know me or my goals and he was discouraging me.
orthopaedics: I didn't meet a single female attending. I also believe I could have died on my assigned stool in the operating room and no one would have noticed.
general_surgery: The one female attending I met was notoriously cruel to students. She was fine with me but I wonder how much the system wore her down.
ob_gyn: Night work is bad for fertility.
urology: I had my negative feedback on this rotation, from a female attending. I felt that she was bullying me rather than giving helpful feedback. I have the impression that to succeed in a male dominated speciality, women often feel the need to take on hyper masculine behaviour akin to an academic drag performance.
are_there_any_other_specif: It's very costly in terms of travelling electives which is a huge deterrent for students from low SES backgrounds. Although we all have access to generous LOCs, I had a significant debt level from living independently early (necessitated by low SES), an obligation to have funds available to send my parent periodically (it's worse for my mental health if they're homeless than it is taking the financial hit), self-funding all my education, and certainly having no inheritance to look forward to. Spending tens of thousands to get interviews at multiple schools and be taken seriously as an applicant for surgery felt entirely out of my reach.

specialty_reason: Personal interest, positive clerkship experiences, research opportunities
discouragement_reason: Discouraging comments based on difficulty with family planning as a surgeon, "male dominated environment", long hours, call burden
orthopaedics: Male-dominated, hypermasculine culture, have witnessed/experienced inappropriate comments to female trainees
general_surgery: Long hours, call culture, strained relationship between attendings and residents
ob_gyn: In house call, call burden
vascular_surgery: Call burden, traditional hierarchal surgical culture
urology: Male-dominated
neurosurgery: Hours, call burden, expectation to do PhD at some programs
are_there_any_other_specif: No

specialty_reason: Not interested
specialty_change: No, just not interested in surgical field and lifestyle. (answered below questions as if I was intending to pursue surgery but technically not applicable to me)
orthopaedics: Work culture, lack of attending positions
general_surgery: n/a
ob_gyn: culture, odd hours, long call
vascular_surgery: hard to get into very small program
urology: call, being a female in a generally male

specialty_reason: I like the challenge, working with my hands, love the OR, being able to complete and see a problem through
discouragement_reason: - wont be able to be a good mother   - wont be able to see my family   - cant study as long as others  - need to choose work over family   - dont tell people you have a partner or have kids or it can negatively affect chances of matching   - selfish for pursuing speciality that will take longer and will require more sacrifice from my family
orthopaedics: Cliche, requires more ability to fit in and like similar interests and hobbies that I noticed vs knowledge/work ethic
general_surgery: Male dominated, unhappy environment, long hours
ob_gyn: Programs differ, some are cliche, negative/heavy environment ,female dominated
urology: Male dominated

specialty_reason: Although I enjoyed my time on surgery, I've enjoyed many aspects of other specialities as well. I'm hoping to pursue a more general speciality that combines both procedure- based aspects with other parts of medicine
specialty_change: Not particularly
are_there_any_other_specif: I think one of the biggest things is exposure early on and throughout clerkship to different surgical specialities. At western, we spend out 4 weeks of Gen surg on the same team, and then have 2 surgical speciality electives. I was quite surprised at how much I enjoyed one of those, and think i may have been more likely to pursue a surgical speciality if I had more time to explore.

specialty_reason: I like procedural work
discouragement_reason: I've had surgeons tell me that it's not the appropriate career for a mother. I've also heard the classic "if you can imagine yourself doing something else, do that"
orthopaedics: Need for multiple fellowships, poor job market
general_surgery: Brutal training, longest hours along with NSx for a program, very difficult royal college exam
ob_gyn: Very difficult training program with long hours
urology: None
neurosurgery: Brutal training, longest # of years (6), poor job market and will likely need to work in the US
cardiac_surgery: Difficult training, but admittedly don't know much about it
are_there_any_other_specif: Rigidity of the system. Other royal college programs have been able to accomodate part time or 80% load for residents. I believe that there is no surgical residency in Canada that has been able to make such accomodation. Having this as an option is important to me as a parent in case childcare falls through or my kids start struggling.

specialty_reason: I am not that interested in surgery and the lifestyle doesn't really match with my goals and family needs.
specialty_change: I found a lot of my surgery rotations to be fairly toxic and felt much more comfortable in medical rotations. The culture and lifestyle did not seem that conducive to having a family.
discouragement_reason: I have been told numerous times some version of "if you really love (____ surgical specialty) then do it but if theres absolutely anything else you think you could be happy in then choose that instead. Only do surgery if you love it."
orthopaedics: Ortho seems to be an especially male-dominated specialty and the culture seemed particularly toxic (mainly because of attendings) at my institution.
general_surgery: - lifestyle, stress, hours of work
ob_gyn: I was actually very drawn to ob/gyn but in the end just didn't love the surgeries that much.
urology: No experience with urology
plastic_surgery: No experience with plastic surgery but have heard that my institution is very demanding and not that supportive of residents.

specialty_reason: residents appear to be treated poorly with little regard for their well-being, ignored by preceptors most of the time with little teaching, sent to do scut work rather than core elements of a surgical clerkship, treated like a burden not a learner, long term outlook for work life balance poor
specialty_change: as someone who initially considered surgery but changed their mind directly as a result of my rotations, the biggest things that would need to change are the OR environment being less hostile towards learners (everyone seems annoyed a student is there most of the time, especially when we don't know the minutiae of expectations the surgeon, assist, resident, and scrub nurses have that seem to vary by OR) and preceptors being more excited to teach and value their medical students and residents.
discouragement_reason: resident had been scheduled 3 Saturdays in a row and was forced to use their single personal day (aka their only true day off that was not a post call day) to plan and host a resident event. said they were exhausted and burnt out. said they were having trouble making ends meet financially.
orthopaedics: not exposed until MS4
general_surgery: poor value for resident wellness, not uncommon for attendings to not learn my name even after being with them every day for a week or two, residents voicing they didn't feel supported
ob_gyn: hostile teaching environment at my site, not uncommon for attendings to not learn my name even after being with them every day for a week or two
ent: extremely toxic work environment with different surgeons fueding against each other at my site and multiple college complaints     mostly stood in OR and ignored for the entire day even if I asked questions as we went

specialty_reason: Time committment required compared to other specialities both in residency and beyond, as well as poor work life balance compared to other specialities.
specialty_change: Likely need to complete a fellowship in order to get a job adds several extra years of difficult training with poor work life balance. Should the job market improve and the need for extra research and fellowships decrease I may have considered surgery more seriously as a specialty choice.
orthopaedics: Physical strength required.
ob_gyn: Poor work life balance for entire career due to frequency of overnight shifts/call compared to most specialities (at least at my training location)

specialty_change: better work-life balance during training making it more flexible for family planning and improved mental health support. I would enjoy a surgical specialty but am nervous that it would change me as a personal going through the training. Not because of the hard work but what i have heard about the training environments.
discouragement_reason: Nothing specific but I was pondering a career in ENT and not a single person I discussed this with (medical students, residents) were not excited but worried for me and made sure I understood the risk and was not sure it aligned with my personal values...

specialty_reason: Considering OBGYN because I enjoy the medicine and patient population but unsure about pursuing a surgical specialty
discouragement_reason: -family members believe it is too difficult and not conducive to a good lifestyle. Specific comments have included "a woman should not work that hard" and "who will take care of your children".
orthopaedics: -lack of job availability
general_surgery: -difficult residency with very long hours  -unsure if it would be feasible to have children during this residency   -male dominated
neurosurgery: -very long training, job availability after training

specialty_reason: Surgical residency seems very intense and demanding. There are stories of residence not leaving the hospital for days. There seems to be no time for family and personal life, which was a big deterrent for me.
orthopaedics: Minimal female representation in orthopaedics. It's important to have a strong support network in residency, which can be missing if you cannot relate to your co-residents, who are predominantly male.

discouragement_reason: - told it is a bad lifestyle if I want to become a mother  - bad lifestyle for someone with an existing autoimmune disease   - stressful   - poor job market   - early mornings  - physically taxing   - toxic culture especially in residency
orthopaedics: Male dominated
general_surgery: Poor lifestyle, hard to make time for family
ob_gyn: Poor lifestyle, hard to make time for family
vascular_surgery: Poor lifestyle, hard to make time for family
urology: Poor lifestyle, hard to make time for family  Male dominated
neurosurgery: Poor lifestyle, hard to make time for family   Male dominated
cardiac_surgery: Poor lifestyle, hard to make time for family   Male dominated
are_there_any_other_specif: Lack of diversity in certain subspecialties

specialty_reason: Like medicine more than surgery
specialty_change: Better residency in terms of work-life balance, prioritizing student wellbeing.
orthopaedics: Job prospects, residency hours.
ob_gyn: Culture, residency hours, attending work-life balance

specialty_reason: interesting mix of cases, like the procedural nature
discouragement_reason: Mostly preceptors from other specialties saying the lifestyle will be tough, especially as a female trainee.
orthopaedics: - hearing stories from female staff about how the 'ortho bro' culture was a deterrent to them  - the physicality of the surgical cases
general_surgery: - the lifestyle including high caseload, emergent cases overnight
ob_gyn: - the need to be in-house even as staff
urology: - male-dominated, less conducive to family planning
neurosurgery: - long training   - lack of wellness support & stories about unhealthy work stress (eg. NSx resident suicide at my school)
cardiac_surgery: -long training  - poor lifestyle  - lack of job opportunities  - 'old boy's club'
are_there_any_other_specif: - the ubiquity of pursuing fellowships in the US to be competitive for urban jobs - and I really don't want to live in the US, even for a short while

specialty_reason: Long hours and difficulty balancing lifestyle. Toxic culture.
specialty_change: More flexible career, less intense and toxic culture.
discouragement_reason: "If you can imagine yourself being happy any specialty that's not surgery, choose that over surgery"
orthopaedics: Bro culture. Long hours.
general_surgery: Long hours, tough lifestyle
ob_gyn: Call shifts and long hours make it difficult to sustain a career over a lifetime.

specialty_reason: lifestyle, primarily. partially for health reasons as well.
specialty_change: probably not, honestly
discouragement_reason: "If you can picture yourself doing anything but surgery, don't do surgery"  "if you like spending less than 100 hours a week in the hospital, don't do surgery"  "if you value your life, don't do surgery"

specialty_reason: Notoriously difficult work-life balance, and many surgeries were tedious to me after seeing them a few times.
specialty_change: Better work-life balance, less toxic cultures, happier residents, more job opportunity, less training required (not just fellowship expectations but expectations for masters or PhD, etc.)
discouragement_reason: Told by many surgical staff and residents to only do surgery if you could not "live without cutting people" or see yourself doing another specialty. Told to pursue anesthesiology if you enjoy being in an OR.
orthopaedics: Unsure, haven't thought about it much, but probably  bias.
general_surgery: Requirements for ++ training after/during residency.
ob_gyn: Work-life balance issues that persist behind residency, fears of being sued, poor outcomes
urology: Unsure
are_there_any_other_specif: Already stated

specialty_reason: The ability to follow patients into the most acute scenarios
discouragement_reason: From many surgical residents - essentially convey that it takes over your entire life and leaves very little behind.
orthopaedics: Culture from staff
general_surgery: Breadth of scope requiring an incredible amount of training in order to be skilled.
ob_gyn: Toxic and unsupportive culture.
plastic_surgery: Highly competitive - need to commit to it early
are_there_any_other_specif: The biggest thing is the need to practice & train so much in order to be a competent staff that most people end up making significant sacrifices in their personal life.

specialty_reason: The lifestyle is not for me. The hours and amount of time on call plus the really horrible stories I hear about surgical specialties. I also do not like the personalities it tends to attract as I find it's a very competitive and cut-throat environment which I am not interested in
specialty_change: Better hours, better residency treatment, more focus on patient education and better interpersonal environment (especially as a learner)
discouragement_reason: It was described to me from a few people that it was not a place for someone who isn't extremely tough and that you just have to accept that you will hate life for 5 to 10 years in residency/fellowship and that you will be getting verbally abused by preceptors throughout (even in clerkship)
orthopaedics: It's a men's club. I have heard there are very few women in the specialty and I am not interested in having to constantly fight to be given the same opportunities as my male colleagues constantly
general_surgery: I have seen quite a few female surgeons in gen surg but I don't think any surg specialty is conducive to a good quality of life, especially if I want to have kids
ob_gyn: I have heard it's an extremely toxic environment for women residents to have children (ironically)
vascular_surgery: All of the vascular surgeons I have met have been men. One of which told our group full of women we would probably become family doctors but singled out our one male colleague as a potential surgeon
urology: I have heard it mostly men in the field and I have heard similar things to ortho about it
neurosurgery: Crazy amount of training years and horrible lifestyle
are_there_any_other_specif: I would be very worried that if I developed arthritis/ issues like that (which will happen with age) I won't be able to do the job I tried 20 years to do. It's too high risk for me

specialty_reason: Love the idea of procedures and working with my hands.
discouragement_reason: Being discouraged due to the lifestyle. Wanting to enjoy my life and spend time with family/friends. Other physicians I know personally said not to pursue surgery unless it's the only thing I can see myself doing.
orthopaedics: Strength/stature/culture
general_surgery: Hours, workload, lack of female attendings, culture of "living at the hospital"
ob_gyn: Call schedule
urology: Male patients

specialty_reason: Enjoy hands on work
discouragement_reason: Specifically interested in orthopedic surgery. Was told I was "too small" for ortho.
orthopaedics: Size/strength as the main barrier. Stigma against women in ortho. Still the most underrepresented field for women.
general_surgery: Stigma against females- although this appears to be improving.
ob_gyn: As a female I feel this is widely accepted. From a male perspective, I could see patient barriers to wanting a male OBGYN.
urology: In previous rotations have noticed that most male patients do not prefer a female to perform sensitive exams.
neurosurgery: Have only met male mentors in this field before.
are_there_any_other_specif: Nil

specialty_reason: The training is too long. I wouldn't wang that lifestyle. I am more interested in the medicine and connecting with people.
specialty_change: the culture and the teaching environment improving
orthopaedics: The culture of orthopaedic surgery, lack of female representation
general_surgery: Gender discrimination, family planning issues
ob_gyn: The environment of OB/GYN feels toxic as a medical student observing the interactions of the team
urology: 'Mentor' in urology makes me feel discouraged about the specialty
cardiac_surgery: Competitiveness and environment and extent of training

specialty_reason: Poor job prospects, long training path taking into account fellowships
specialty_change: Improved job market
discouragement_reason: Advised of the long residency hours and difficulty finding a job in major cities upon graduation
orthopaedics: None
general_surgery: None
ob_gyn: Feel disadvantaged as a male applicant
vascular_surgery: Very small residency, feel it would be difficult to get into having not been gunning from it early on
urology: Popular as a lifestyle surgical specialty. It may be difficult to get into having not been gunning from it early on.
ent: Popular as a lifestyle surgical specialty. It may be difficult to get into having not been gunning from it early on.
plastic_surgery: Popular as a lifestyle surgical specialty. It may be difficult to get into having not been gunning from it early on.
are_there_any_other_specif: Haven't enjoyed being in the OR.     Concerned it may be hard to have a family in surgery given long length of training with long hours and possible need to uproot for job prospects.

specialty_reason: Quality of life and future plans
specialty_change: Better work hours, and despite being really interested in the procedures and theory behind it, I find standing up and having procedures get drawn out for a long time to be kind of boring.
general_surgery: Very long hours and calls
ob_gyn: I feel like men are kind of discouraged to do this
neurosurgery: Too much stress and long surgeries

specialty_reason: Considered it but the deciding factor was how much I wanted all my work to be with my hands.
specialty_change: No.
orthopaedics: Male dominated
general_surgery: Post call day culture
ob_gyn: NA
urology: NA
are_there_any_other_specif: No

specialty_reason: bad worklife balance
specialty_change: better work life balance, more inclusive for women
orthopaedics: sounds to macho and most people are buff/sporty
general_surgery: bad work life balance, everyone hates themselves
ob_gyn: people are mean and they have horrible work life balance
urology: good worklife balance, but do not want to deal with this kind of work
cardiac_surgery: extremely sexist, like cardiology you will have patients who sexually harass you most likely, and colleagues are sexist
are_there_any_other_specif: sexism  lack of female colleagues  horrible work life balance

specialty_reason: Did not enjoy surgical environment, long training hours and hope to match closer to family i.e. competitive
specialty_change: Less strenuous residency, not having to be on call for rest of life, desire for good work-life balance, not comfortable with alternatives to childcare practices seen commonly among surgical attendings
orthopaedics: Boys club
general_surgery: Long hours
ob_gyn: Unsupportive OR environment
urology: Boys club
neurosurgery: Highly competitive, poor work life balance, intense personalities

specialty_reason: I do want to have a family and I think family medicine seems to have a much better work life balance than most of the surgical specialties. Residency also seems pretty terrible in the surgical specialties.
specialty_change: Better work life balance, especially in residency.
orthopaedics: This is one that I do feel is heavily male dominated. The long residency and fellowship is also a deterrent.
general_surgery: How competitive it is to get into, and also the lifestyle during residency seems like a barrier.
ob_gyn: I've heard that a lot of OB/GYN surgeons are quite rude and grumpy and I'm a bit afraid that residency/the OB/GYN lifestyle is what made them grumpy and detached from their patients.
urology: N/A
are_there_any_other_specif: I want to have a longitudinal relationship with my patients and help them work on their health as a whole and I fee like the surgical specialties are quite detached from their patients.

specialty_reason: I dreamed of becoming a urologist but got rejected twice in a row.
specialty_change: Accessibility to residency programs, especially for low income / 1st generation medical students.
discouragement_reason: "You need a plug to get in"  "You will burn out"
urology: Lack of ethnic representation among mentors.  Gender bias specific to urology favors women a bit more nowadays because of historical lack of representation, which is great for increasing diversity but is to the detriment of male candidates.   very little room in residency programs.
are_there_any_other_specif: Necessity of having a history of "gunning" for surgery; meaning having mentors very early on, and being exposed prior to clerkship (usually seen in people who are not 1st gen medical students). no room for late bloomers

specialty_reason: Lenght training/need fellowship, poor job market ortho, brutal hours residency
specialty_change: More community programs, more personal life conciliation
orthopaedics: Poor job market
general_surgery: Lots of call
ob_gyn: Harsh personality of coworkers, 24 hour calls no post call day as staff
urology: Male dominated, poor knowledge of female oriented practice
are_there_any_other_specif: Wanting to have time with children while having them during residency because of older age

specialty_reason: I love procedures and the tangible impact you make on patient's lives. Can't see myself doing anything else.
discouragement_reason: I was told by a female surgeon in the subspecialty I ended up applying to not to do it and that if she could do it again, she would have done pathology. She's the only one who told me not to do surgery, and the only female surgeon in that subspecialty at my clerkship site. I didn't let it deter me however. I still applied to otolaryngology.
orthopaedics: I was told by a male ortho attending that my hands were too small to be an orthopedic surgeon. I wear size 6 gloves and am 5 feet tall. I told the site rotation lead who was a female ortho surgeon and she reassured me if I wanted to do it I could, but I didn't feel like I belonged.
are_there_any_other_specif: No. I have seen the women who have broken the proverbial glass ceiling and have accomplished the goals I have for myself. I know it's not easy but I want to be a surgeon and know the road will be challenging but that doesn't change that I truly feel this is my purpose and calling.

specialty_reason: I didn't like the OR. I like having control over my schedule.
specialty_change: The residency is really intimidating.
discouragement_reason: I think it's common for people to say "if you can picture yourself doing anything else, do that"
orthopaedics: Boys club
general_surgery: I've heard stories of gen surg programs being unsupported of female residents during pregnancy.
ob_gyn: I've never felt so disregarded as on this rotation. I would be in a conversation and was expected to just pretend I didn't exist.
urology: no interest in this
cardiac_surgery: There were no female attendings with kids.
are_there_any_other_specif: I remember going to a career panel in 1st year medical school and the topic of families came up. All of the female surgeons told stories about how difficult it was and how unsupported they felt by their residency program. One told the story of attendings joking that she didn't know how to use birth control. As an older female medical student who would like to have children this was a huge deterrent to me.

specialty_reason: Interested in ability to make a direct impact, enjoy working with my hands
discouragement_reason: Told to pursue a specialty where I would have more time to raise children
orthopaedics: "Boys club" culture within the specialty
general_surgery: "Boys club" culture within the specialty
ob_gyn: High stress, busy call, did not personally enjoy the pathologies, automatic assumption that a female student interested in surgery=an OBGYN
urology: Patients reluctance to be seen by female surgeons
neurosurgery: Long hours/call not conducive to family/life outside the hospital
cardiac_surgery: Long hours/call not conducive to family/life outside the hospital

specialty_reason: Interested in the operative aspect and variety. Enjoy the bread and butter of general surgery.
discouragement_reason: Told to reconsider because its hard to start a family on one instance. Otherwise, i was usually highly encouraged.
orthopaedics: Male dominated specialty creates barriers for mentorship and for forming connections that allow for career advancement and opportunities.
general_surgery: Long training requiring msot to pursue research and fellowship. Rigorous training making it tough to take time off for fertility/family planning.
ob_gyn: Bad culture. Female dominated but oddly a very judgmental culture.
urology: Male dominated
ent: I do Not have enough exposure
plastic_surgery: I do Not have enough exposure
neurosurgery: I do Not have enough exposure
cardiac_surgery: I do Not have enough exposure
are_there_any_other_specif: Fear of intimidation from male attendings

specialty_reason: Lifestyle and hours during residency
specialty_change: more time off for mat leave, post call days, less call, less hours in the hospital
orthopaedics: make dominant and witnessed bullying culture
general_surgery: long hours and disrespect towards female residents observed during clerkship
ob_gyn: unkind culture towards other residents
ent: Long training, some programs do not have post call days, limited number of female mentors
plastic_surgery: Limited number of supportive female mentors and residents

discouragement_reason: Just general discouragement because the life style is so busy
orthopaedics: requires interest in sports
neurosurgery: Boys club, very heavy work load and hours

specialty_reason: Decided that the lifestyle wasn't worth it for me. Was worried I wasn't going to be able to continue my hobbies and start a family.
specialty_change: I wish the culture of surgery was better. I felt like I had to give up my life outside of medicine to pursue a surgical residency, which sucks because it was dream but I felt like I had to let go of that.  I saw a lot of residents during my surgical blocks of clerkship who were miserable and regretting choosing surgery because they were getting minimal sleep, were stressed, and were having troubles maintaining a life outside of medicine. I get that you have to work hard so that you are knowledgeable coming out of residency but I wish there was more of a place for balance and residents were more supported
discouragement_reason: At least more than 5 separate occasions with surgical residents during clerkship, I was told not to do surgery and that they had regrets. Many said they probably would've been happier choosing something else. That stuck with me.
orthopaedics: Mostly men. Seems like you need to be physically strong for some of the procedures. Lack of female mentors.
general_surgery: Seemed to have the worst culture in terms of workload. Some of the staff also stick out as not being the kindest to med students
ob_gyn: Western specifically is known to have a poor culture for this specialty. Many of my friends from other schools know this as well. Mainly that staff and residents are not kind to students and even each other (which is sad)
vascular_surgery: Haven't had much exposure to this specialty
urology: Have only really heard good things
ent: Competitive but western my experience with residents and staff has always been positive

specialty_reason: Immediate satisfaction of "fixing" something, working with my hands, love the OR
discouragement_reason: Nearly every non-surgical staff I have told about wanting to pursue surgery, discouraged me from doing so in some way (some more subtle than others). For most people it was comments like "do you hate your life?", "do you not want kids" or "I'm worried for you". There was always a "are you sure?" in the conversation too which my classmates wanting to pursue medical specialties never got.
orthopaedics: Strength requirements for hip replacements
general_surgery: The large scopes used for colonoscopy/EGD aren't optimized for use by people with smaller hands (which happen to often be females)
ob_gyn: None
urology: Patient factors - male patients preferring male clinicians
neurosurgery: Length of training (including CIP) may be a deterrent for those wanting to start a family
are_there_any_other_specif: Residency programs not outwardly welcoming women starting families during residency - many of us start residency in our late 20s / early 30s and with fertility issues being so pervasive amongst surgical trainees, it should be no surprise that female residents start families during residency and they should be well supported when doing so (I.e. clear policies on leave that are easy to find, not getting grief from staff about doing a very normal human thing, etc.). I applied to a surgical specialty this year and my rank list was certainly impacted by whether or not the program brought up supporting leave in residency in their meet and greet/social events.

specialty_reason: I love working with my hands and I love being in the OR and I love anatomy.
orthopaedics: Boys club
general_surgery: Less barriers, but female surgeons may be encouraged to see more breast cases than their male peers. One surgical group in my area unifficially designated their female partner as the breast surgeon. She sees all the breast issues. Obviously she had a say in the matter and agreed but I don't think that kind of thinking would have happened if she was a male.
ob_gyn: This might be a little more bias towards females
urology: Biased towards males but for the same reason Obgyn is biased towards females. At that point I think patient preferences for male or female physicians for more sensitive issues is ok. (Utah has very few female Obgyns so patients are "forced" to see male obgyns. The males are great and I've worked with them, but still young patients may want to see a female provider)
ent: Some bias toward men, but more female representation is happening. This is the field I'm planning on pursuing.
neurosurgery: Boys club. Length of training is insane for me personally. Planning to have children around this residency would be a nightmare. Fertility preservation would be a concern.
are_there_any_other_specif: At this time in my life, I don't really have any big things that would prevent me from pursuing that career. If I currently had any children that would probably influence my decision. But I don't right now so why would I hold myself back?

discouragement_reason: By peers, staff, family

specialty_reason: It has been presented as having horrible work life balance, being overworked and very difficult to have a family.
specialty_change: All of the things mentioned above
discouragement_reason: A resident I met at a bar who had just switched from surgery into family medicine because they were completely overworked and burned out. They said that they were finally beginning to feel like themselves again now that they were out and strongly advised not to go into surgery if you want any sort of happiness.
are_there_any_other_specif: Ability to take a maternity leave without penalization (formal or informal)

specialty_reason: Work-life balance, competitiveness, culture
specialty_change: Call-schedule
discouragement_reason: Residents describing the bad work-life balance who are in a surgery specialty

specialty_reason: Negative experiences with both surgeons and surgical residents, hostile learning environment, condescending staff, many attendings I work with are friendly with residents and do lots of teaching with them but barely interact with medical students, deterring in terms of finding a mentor who would encourage you to pursue their surgical specialty, lots of call, pressure when in the OR to know what to do
orthopaedics: Male-dominated field
ob_gyn: Lots of medico-legal issues

specialty_reason: Long hours, poor work life balance, long residency, toxic residency environment, expectation that job comes before anything else
specialty_change: Better work life balance. Better pay within residency equating to the hours worked. Reduced hours working once in a staff position
orthopaedics: Poor job opportunities post training. Has a reputation as being a "frat boy" specialty. Personal experience with orthopaedic surgeons has been poor.
general_surgery: Long hours. Call.
ob_gyn: I would actually be very interested in this specialty if the work life balance wasnt so terrible
urology: Witnessed a bad outcome during an observership which has deterred me
plastic_surgery: Interested but long residency not so much
neurosurgery: Very long residency with few jobs available in the cities I would want to work in
are_there_any_other_specif: Feels like things can change so rapidly and a routine procedure could lead to death which is scary

specialty_reason: Poor lifestyle: poor flexibility of hours, no desire to be on call, poor culture/reputation for shame based learning, long residency
specialty_change: Primarily the culture (especially shame based learning) and the long hours with call (I can't see this changing)
orthopaedics: Bro culture
general_surgery: Shame based learning
ob_gyn: Other surgical specialties thinking OBGYN is not surgical, lots of litigation

specialty_reason: Poor work-life balance, lifestyle,
specialty_change: Better work-life balance, fewer on-call times, better job availabilities. Better support for maternity leaves
discouragement_reason: A former Gen Surgery told me that some of the cons of surgery are the legal issues and the high risk of litigation.

specialty_reason: Not interested in performing surgeries (squeamish, disinterested in anatomy, low confidence in dexterity/hand-eye coordination), dissuaded by the lifestyle and brutal residency culture.
specialty_change: Better hours and a more supportive environment would help, but I think my disinterest in a procedural specialty is primarily a personal factor with minimal structural influence
discouragement_reason: a close friend in clerkship, who has very similar lifestyle and values to me, was told by a surgical resident she should not pursue surgery because she has too many hobbies. She passed this on to me.
orthopaedics: interest
general_surgery: interest
ob_gyn: interest, stories of toxic culture at my home institution
urology: interest
plastic_surgery: interest, known competitiveness of program entry

specialty_reason: lifestyle.
specialty_change: no.
orthopaedics: I dont like bones
are_there_any_other_specif: no

specialty_reason: no strong interest in surgery, lifestyle too rigorous, did not feel that residents were similar to me in personality
specialty_change: -better hours  -more supportive resident community
orthopaedics: -"ortho bro" stereotype
general_surgery: -perceived as "mean"   -very long hours, high expectations of residents
ob_gyn: -little control over hours   -have heard it perceived as "not a real surgical soecialty" by other surgeons
urology: -men may want a male doctor for this area of medicine   -definitely feels like a male specialty
ent: No significant experience in this area
plastic_surgery: No significant experience in this area
neurosurgery: -have heard that hours are very bad, would be a barrier for me personally
cardiac_surgery: No significant experience in this area

specialty_reason: Horror stories about work life balance, call shifts, toxic environment (especially with Ortho and some others).
specialty_change: Change in social environment. Some personalities (quieter, less social folk) seem not to flourish. Also, attendings in some specialities are famously toxic (OBGYN, ortho, general surgery, plastics) and would need to change generations and hands.
discouragement_reason: female resident  in surgery describing their experience.

specialty_reason: There should be a maybe option here. I have not decided yet.
specialty_change: Improved work/life balance. I've heard from surgical residents that 15 hour days are a normal occurrence - that doesn't leave time to do basic daily activities to take care of yourself, much less maintain interpersonal relationships.
discouragement_reason: I've been told by people outside of medicine that I should pursue family medicine because it would give me time to focus on my future family, as a woman.
orthopaedics: "boys club" reputation
neurosurgery: Extremely long hours and long residency

specialty_reason: Long hours in training (residency) and in career
specialty_change: Maybe if there's a better work life balance, such as shorter shifts or more flexible scheduling     Also, because surgical specialities are more competitive when looking for jobs
discouragement_reason: Said I have dumb hands

specialty_reason: Lifestyle
0 interest in surgery as a technique.
specialty_change: no, just not interested in performing surgery itself.

specialty_reason: I do not enjoy the stress of the operating room; the training is too rigorous and long for my preference; the residency match process is too competitive; I am seeking a good work-life balance in my career and I see that being a challenge in surgery
specialty_change: I don't think there would be anything specific that could change my perspective. It is a challenging discipline by nature, which why such rigorous training and long hours are required. The discipline inherently requires perfection of hands-on skills in the operating, which you have to enjoy practicing in order to master.
discouragement_reason: I had a vasovagal episode during a surgical procedure at one time and was told that "perhaps other specialties may suit me better". It was said in a well-meaning manner, however the undertone was that I would not be well suited for surgery. I did not take major offense because I did not have interest in a surgical discipline, but I could see how someone interested in surgery might be discouraged.
orthopaedics: Reputation is that it is a male-dominated specialty. An "old boys club", I have heard.
ob_gyn: Reputation is that it is a female-dominated specialty, with males seen as "out of place".
neurosurgery: Has the reputation for being the most challenging discipline and training program in medicine.

specialty_reason: I want to have children and not have the demands of a surgical residency
specialty_change: More maternity considerations
orthopaedics: Strength
general_surgery: Time demands
ob_gyn: On call
urology: Residency demands

specialty_reason: Not comfortable with cutting people
orthopaedics: i feel i'd be too weak
general_surgery: not comfortable with the workload
ob_gyn: poor work life balance
urology: not interested in this specialty

specialty_reason: Poor work life balance
specialty_change: Better training experience and work life balance
discouragement_reason: Disparaging comments about residency workload and career prospects.
orthopaedics: Male dominated
general_surgery: Poor quality of life
ob_gyn: Toxic culture for co-residents
urology: none

specialty_reason: Love the hands-on, fast paced, high acuity nature of it and felt most like where I belonged
discouragement_reason: No serious comments or anything directed at me, but plenty of people have told me to choose anything but surgery if you can avoid it
orthopaedics: "Bro" stereotype, mostly male, job market, call schedules
general_surgery: Busy lifestyle, specialty was previously known to have a bit of a toxic culture
ob_gyn: Female dominated, focus on women's health
vascular_surgery: Small subspecialty so competitive, very challenging hours
urology: possible bias against females due to large patient population of males
ent: Increasing interest in the field therefore general competition, knowledge about quite a broad spectrum of topics/systems
neurosurgery: Very niche, competitive, research driven (almost requirement to get PhD)
cardiac_surgery: Competitive, gruelling hours and work, sick patients, long residency

specialty_reason: Culture, work hours, post-call operating being unsafe
specialty_change: culture around feedback and teaching styles are outdated and not up to date with evidence. Post-call operating is expected and residents thus need to do it despite breaching working hours. Rampant narcissism and high egos that often makes operating rooms toxic for most involved.

specialty_reason: Lifestyle is incompatible with what I'm looking for.
specialty_change: Better work life balance.
ob_gyn: By far the most toxic culture and lack of professionalism.
cardiac_surgery: This is the only one I was really considering but the hours and lifestyle during residency and beyond is not compatible with the life I want to live.

specialty_reason: procedural
discouragement_reason: administration explicitly vocalized my inability to pursue a surgical speciality due to cultural expectations

specialty_reason: The work seems very rewarding
discouragement_reason: This was by various friends who are in upper year med as well as attendings and residents at other institutions. Have also heard about strong nepotism in hiring practicing for attending surgeon positions
orthopaedics: Poor job market, nepotism in hiring
general_surgery: Nepotism in hiring, appears to be incompatible with having a quality family life
ob_gyn: As a male, I am not as interested
vascular_surgery: Insane hours, incompatible with having a quality family life/relationship
urology: long hours
are_there_any_other_specif: I am interested in doing translational research and surgery doesn't seem like a good fit because there would barely be enough time left over to do research (not sure about protected research time as an attending)

specialty_reason: Not interested in that area of medicine, feel like I have different set of skills that would be suited elsewhere.
specialty_change: I believe that my skills as a physician would be better suited in other areas of medicine.    However, the long hours, call shifts, and stereotypical negative atmosphere of residency in surgical fields definitely further reduce my interest in these areas

specialty_reason: The hours and length of training are not conducive to having a family.
specialty_change: I would have considered it if I didn't hear that every surgical subspeciality does not lend itself to a work life balance. I think there are systemic issues as well as PR issues.
orthopaedics: Radiation and pregnancy

specialty_reason: I want to be an ob/gyn, I love working with women!
discouragement_reason: won't be able to have a family, won't be taken seriously if I want to be surgeon who also wants kids

specialty_reason: I would love to be a surgeon. But the length, difficulty and timing of residency training is not conducive for a woman starting a family. My residency will be during my prime child-bearing years and I do not want to give these up for my career. Additionally, the on-call and long hour work schedule for attending surgeons is also not conducive for me to be the involved parent I want to be for my children.
specialty_change: See above. Ultimately, the structure of residency and surgical work flow does not support child-bearing or effective child-rearing in my opinion. Major overhauls to the surgical/residency system would be needed for this to change. In essence, the current system seems to be made for young men.
discouragement_reason: When expressing to female surgical mentors my desire to have children before age 35 (therefore during residency), I was explicitly told this would make me very disliked by programs and fellow residents. I was encouraged to either delay child bearing or seek non-surgical fields.
orthopaedics: Heavily male-dominated. Difficult for female students to bond with potential mentors. Attendings/residents look for "ortho-bros" to be friends with and get close to.
general_surgery: Tumultuous working hours and grueling residency training.
ob_gyn: Extremely demanding working hours and call schedules.
urology: Seemingly male-dominated. Personally don't prefer working with male genitals.
ent: Prestigious and research-focused. I feel like taking time off in residency to have children would particularly make you un-liked by colleagues in the field.
plastic_surgery: Applicant pool diluted with young, male trainees driven by financial motivations rather than clinical and who use unethical means to put down others to put themselves ahead.
neurosurgery: Extremely grueling and lengthy residency training, possibly long working hours and call schedules as attending. Very long procedures which are physically taxing on the surgeon.
are_there_any_other_specif: Highly competitive fields like ophthalmology, ENT and plastics have a very toxic applicant pools. I have been victim to purposeful sabotage by classmates in order to put me down and themselves ahead. This has made me reconsider these fields altogether.

specialty_reason: Lifestyle not compatible with my family-centeredness
specialty_change: Fewer calls and better hours during residency (<50 hrs/wk)

specialty_reason: Not the best fit for me
specialty_change: No
discouragement_reason: There's been comments made by med students/residents/staff that if you want a big family you shouldn't go into surgery. As someone who wants 4 children, these comments would have been hard to hear if I was actually interested in the specialty.

specialty_reason: Interest and precious exposure to field
residency lifestyle, length of training
specialty_change: residency lifestyle - long hours, culture that neglects mental health
